ZT2Strings.LOC_STRING: Gather a sample from a diseased animal.
Gather a sample from an item in your zoo.
A sample taken in or near the exhibit could yield clues to the cause.
Research results indicate %s may be the cause.
Gather a sample from another item in your zoo.
A sample taken in or near the exhibit may yield the cure.
Research results indicate %s is effective.
Analyzing ...
Data from this sample indicates you're one step closer to finding the cure!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else, or press H for a new research hint.
Your zoo is free from the disease, even though the cure was not found.
The disease in your zoo has cleared up, but you didn't find the cure. The disease might return later.
One or more of your animals has digestive difficulties. Gather a sample from one.
To diagnose the disease, gather more samples from around your zoo for analysis.
Something smelly in or near the animal's exhibit may yield a clue.
Ewww, too much poop in the exhibit may be the cause! Gather a sample for further analysis. Ewww!
What might solve this problem? Gather some samples from around the zoo for analysis.
Maybe we need someplace to put all this poop?
Research results indicate an organic process could help turn the poop into something useful.
Gather a sample from a compost building, so your research team can work on a cure.
The lab is analyzing your sample...
Data from this sample indicates you're one step closer to finding the cure!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
Gather a sample from a diseased animal -- one with germ symbols above its head.
An item in or near the animal's exhibit may yield a clue to the cause.
Many of your zoo's extinct animals are not immune to modern-day bacteria.
Something from your guests may be making your extinct animals sick. Gather a sample from an item a guest leaves behind.
Research results indicate your animals have a disease called the Litter Bug!
Gather a sample from a piece of trash, or even a trash can.
Could a tree hold the key to the cure?
Gather samples from trees in your extinct animals' exhibits.
Desert, grassland, or alpine? One of these biomes has the tree that unlocks the cure.
Research indicates a sample of %s is needed.
The lab is analyzing your sample...
That sample has given us more information about the cure!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
We need a sample from an animal with the slowing syndrome. Look for an animal with Z's above it.
Whoa! Your animals are moving more and more slowly. Can you find the reason why?
Your research team's data on the speedy syndrome may help. Could the two syndromes be connected?
Your research team is taking an early break after eating hot dogs for lunch.
Did you get a hot dog sample to the lab?
It's likely that a plant holds the key to the cure.
Desert, grassland, alpine, or tundra? One of these biomes has the plant that unlocks the cure.
Research indicates a sample of %s is needed.
Your research team is analyzing your sample...
You're one step closer to curing the disease!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
We need a sample from an animal affected by the speedy syndrome.
Your animals are hyperactive! What could have caused this?
Your research team is taking a coffee break.
Snap! Coffee?! Could caffeine be the cause?
Gather a sample from a coffee stand in your zoo.
Plants are usually helpful in finding disease cures.
Desert, grassland, alpine, or tundra? One of these biomes has the plant that unlocks the cure.
Research indicates a sample of %s is needed.
Your research team is analyzing your sample...
That's right! You're closer to finishing the cure!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
Meow! Your big cats may have cat-scratch fever. Gather a sample from a cat with 'itchy' symbols above its head.
What's making these cats itch?
Could a cat enrichment item be the cause?
Scratch, scratch, scratch ...
Gather a sample from a scratching post. If the exhibit is without it, add one.
Leaves from certain plants often have medicinal qualities.
Are there any plants that help with itchy skin?
Perhaps a moisturizing salve would soothe your itchy cats.
Try sampling some desert plants, perhaps from South Africa.
Your research team thinks that aloe vera might be the piece you're looking for.
Your research team is analyzing your sample...
That's right! You're closer to finishing the cure!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
Pink elephants! Oh, my! The research team would like you to gather a sample from one.
What's causing the elephants to turn pink?
Could one of their enrichment items be the cause?
Do your elephants play with anything that's pink?
Gather a sample from a pursuit ball.
Your research team wonders if samples from anything pink could hold the key to the cure -- even if it's not in your zoo.
Search beyond the exhibit. Maybe it's something guests use.
Hey! What about that fluffy cloud of spun sugar that's also called "candy floss"? Doesn't it come from a pink food cart?!
Quick! Gather a sample from a cotton candy cart!
Your research team is testing your sample...
Of course! You're getting closer to curing your pink elephants!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
Your dodo has the Tutorial Love disease! Walk up to the dodo with the hearts around its head, and press the SPACEBAR to take a sample.
Your first research report! Walk up to the dodo with the hearts around its head, and press the SPACEBAR to take a sample.
Find the dodo with the hearts over its head. Walk up to it, and press the SPACEBAR to take a sample.
You need to sample some fruit for analysis.
Try sampling the bananas.
Walk up to the food dish with bananas, and press the SPACEBAR to take a sample.
The disease cure is bright pink!
Try getting a sample of the pursuit ball!
Walk up to the pursuit ball, and press the SPACEBAR to take a sample.
Your research team is analyzing your sample...
Yes! You found one of the items to cure the disease!
Analysis indicates this item doesn't unlock the cure. Sample something else or press H for a new research hint.
Your research team is not interested in a round, young tree. Sample something older.
The lab is researching helicopter seeds.
Look for the grassland tree with seeds falling from it.
Gather a sample from a boxelder tree.
Your research team is puzzled by this disease.
Most monkey species don't like cold weather!
This alpine tree grows in the Andes.
Gather a sample from a monkey puzzle tree to cure the disease.
The cure you seek may lead you to a tree with prickly, pointy leaves. Watch out!
Small birds and tiny animals live in this tree.
Research results indicate a large desert tree is the cure.
Gather a sample from the saguaro cactus.
The plant you seek has thick green leaves.
It holds considerable amounts of water.
This desert plant blooms once every 100 years.
Your research team discovered that the agave cactus century plant is the cure.
The plant you seek has thick green leaves.
It holds considerable amounts of water
The plant that holds the key to the cure is a desert plant.
Your research team discovered that the agave cactus is the cure.
This item is renowned for its medicinal properties.
This plant has fleshy, pointed leaves.
Search the desert biomes for this plant.
The aloe vera unlocks the cure.
Could an herb cure this disease?
This herb sometimes blossoms with pink flowers.
This grassland plant grows all over the world.
Your research team requests a sample of daisies.
This disease requires a cure from a strong plant.
This plant is related to the rhododendron.
This hearty plant found on the tundra holds the key to the cure.
Sample the dwarf azalea to discover the cure.
Something bright and blooming may cure this disease.
This plant is the floral emblem of Switzerland.
This plant grows high in the Alps.
The edelweiss holds the key to the cure.
This cycad appeared in a report from your research team.
This cycad tree dominated the landscape in the Jurassic Period.
It's sometimes called the "king" of rainforest trees.
The King Sago Palm unlocks the cure.
A feathery plant unlocks the cure to this disease.
Often called feather grass, this plant may not be in your zoo yet.
An evergreen, you can find it in New Zealand or growing in some alpine biomes.
A blade of speargrass is just what the doctor ordered.
The item you seek grows in the meadows of North America.
Waving in prairie winds, this plant has a golden hue.
This grassland plant can grow up to 2 m (6 ft)!
The tall goldenrod holds the key to the cure.
What items in or near the exhibit could be the source?
Many of your zoo's extinct animals are not immune to modern-day bacteria.
Could your guests be making your animals sick? Gather a sample from something a guest leaves behind.
Your research team has a name for this disease. They call it the Litter Bug.
Gather a sample from a piece of trash, or a trash can.
Digestive Difficulties
Litter Bug
Slowing Syndrome
Speedy Syndrome
Cat-scratch Fever
Pink Elephants!
